title: Popular online travel agency announces takeover bid
text:
H﻿elloworld Travel has launched a takeover bid for online travel agent Webjet.

Webjet announced that under the non-binding offer, Helloworld would acquire 100 per cent of the remaining shares in Webject at 90 cents a share.

Helloworld currently has a 17.27 per cent stake in Webjet.

READ MORE: Trump hurls outrageous slur at female reporter

Online travel agent Webjet has announced a takeover bid by Helloworld Travel. (Webjet)

The takeover offer is subject to a number of conditions, including a satisfactory completion of due diligence by Helloworld; entry into a scheme implementation deed with customary terms and conditions; and a unanimous favourable recommendation from the Webjet board.

That recommendation will also require the absence of any superior proposal, and an independent expert's confirmation that the sale was in the best interests of Webjet shareholders.

Regulatory approvals and approvals from shareholders and the courts are also required.

READ MORE: Huge vote on Epstein files after Trump backflip

Helloworld would purchase all shares it does not currently control at 90 cents apiece. (9News)

The purchase would be funded through a combination of cash on balance sheet, and new debt facilities, Webjet said.

The board has agreed to provide Helloworld with an opportunity to conduct due diligence, noting that no binding offer was in place.

Shareholders have been told they do not have to currently take any action, and that more announcements will come.﻿

title: Stocks drop after another jarring day on Wall Street
text:
The US stock market fell after another jarring day, as worries keep dogging Nvidia, bitcoin and other Wall Street stars that their prices shot too high.

After quickly sliding to a morning loss of 1.5 per cent, the S&P 500 clawed back nearly all of it before sinking again.

It finished with a fall of 0.8 per cent and pulled further from its all-time high set late last month. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 498 points, or 1.1 per cent, and the Nasdaq composite sank 1.2 per cent.

READ MORE: Trump hurls outrageous slur at female reporter

Specialist Anthony Matesic and trader Patrick Casey work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. (AP)

The shaky finish on Wall Street was felt in the Australian share market, which fell at the opening of trade before steadying to go up 0.5 per cent up at midday.

In the US, Nvidia was again the heaviest weight on the market, and its drop of 2.8 per cent brought its loss for the month so far to more than 10 per cent.

That’s a steep enough fall that Wall Street has a name for it: a correction.

What Nvidia does matters disproportionately to savers’ 401(k) accounts because its immense size means it’s the most influential stock on Wall Street. Those 401(k) accounts are the equivalent of Australia's superannuation funds.

It single-handedly steers the direction of the S&P 500 some days, after fervent demand for its artificial-intelligence chips helped it briefly top $5 trillion in total value.

The US stock market’s recent struggles are a sharp turnaround from its nearly relentless rally since April, when Wall Street last sold off after President Donald Trump shocked the world with stiff tariffs.

READ MORE: Huge vote on Epstein files after Trump backflip

Trader Anan Patel works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Tuesday, Nov. 18, 2025. (AP Photo/Richard Drew) (AP)

That rally was so strong that critics say it may have carried prices too high, too fast and left the market at risk of a sharp drop.

They point in particular to stocks swept up in the AI mania, which have been surging at spectacular speeds for years.

Nvidia’s price more than doubled in four of the last five years, for example, while Palantir Technologies’ stock more than doubled in the first six and a half months of this year.

Many big investors still seem to expect stock prices to rise further, according to the latest monthly survey of global fund managers by Bank of America Global Research.

But when asked what the No. 1 risk for the market is, one with a lower probability of happening but a chance of very big damage, 45 per cent pointed to an AI bubble.

That beat out potential trouble in the bond market, inflation and trade wars.

Options trader Joseph D'Arrigo works on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange, Tuesday, Nov. 18, 2025. (AP Photo/Richard Drew)

A record percentage of investors is also saying companies are “overinvesting,” according to the survey.

The worry is that all the dollars pouring into AI chips and data centers worldwide may not produce the kind of revolution that AI proponents have been predicting, or at least not as profitable a one.

Other high-flying areas of the market with their own evangelists have also been struggling lately.

Bitcoin’s price briefly fell below $US90,000 ($138,000) in the morning, down from nearly $US125,000 last month. It later recovered some of its losses and climbed back toward $US93,000.

Home Depot also dragged the market lower after falling 6 per cent.

It reported a weaker profit for the summer than analysts expected and cited a variety of reasons.

Chief among them was a lack of storms, which would have driven customers to buy more home-improvement supplies.

Home Depot chief executive Ted Decker also pointed to “consumer uncertainty and continued pressure in housing” for preventing an expected increase in demand.

Reporting stronger profits is one of the ways a company can make its stock price look less expensive, because stock prices tend to track with earnings over the long term.

That’s raising the stakes for tomorrow's profit report from Nvidia, which could either help halt its stock’s slide or worsen it.

Elsewhere on Wall Street, Cloudflare fell 2.8 per cent after an earlier issue at the internet infrastructure provider caused global outages for ChatGPT and other services.

All told, the S&P 500 fell 55.09 points to 6,617.32.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 498.50 to 46,091.74, and the Nasdaq composite sank 275.23 to 22,432.85.

In the bond market, Treasury yields likewise oscillated through the day.

The yield on the 10-year Treasury eventually eased to 4.11 per cent from 4.13 per cent late Monday.

Yields have been swinging amid doubts about whether the Federal Reserve will cut its main interest rate at its next meeting in December, something that traders had earlier seen as very likely.

What the Fed does is critical for the market because stock prices ran to records in part because of expectations for continued cuts to rates.

The Fed has cut rates twice already this year in hopes of shoring up a slowing job market.

But lower interest rates can make inflation worse, and inflation has stubbornly remained above the Fed’s two per cent target.

In stock markets abroad, indexes tumbled across Europe and Asia.

South Korea’s Kospi sank 3.3 per cent, Japan’s Nikkei 225 dropped 3.2 per cent and France’s CAC 40 fell 1.9 per cent for some of the world’s larger drops.

title: The $110,000 fine you could face if your dog has puppies
text:
P﻿uppy breeders and owners in New South Wales could face massive fines exceeding $110,000 after new laws come into effect next month.

The state government is cracking down on illegal backyard breeding and puppy farming, including ﻿a strict cap on the number of litters a dog can have over its lifetime, from December 1.

The tougher laws aim to make it easier for families looking to buy a new puppy to find an "ethical and accountable breeder", the NSW government said.

READ MORE: Trump hurls outrageous slur at female reporter

The NSW government is cracking down on illegal puppy farming and backyard breeding with new laws. (Joe Armao)

﻿This fresh legislation is captured under the NSW Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Amendment (Puppy Farming) Act 2024.

Here's everything you need to know about the upcoming law changes.﻿

You'll need a new identification number﻿

The first change will require all NSW puppy breeders to have something called a Breeder Identification Number (BIN)﻿.

A BIN is given free of charge when breeders create a profile on the NSW Pet Registry.

The government has introduced identification numbers to assist buyers in finding an ethical breeder.

There are exceptions to this rule – including rehoming organisations caring for a surrendered pregnant dog and farmers breeding working dogs that will remain on their land.﻿

More transparency in puppy ads﻿

Breeders advertising the sale or transfer of dogs will also be required to include key identifying information.

This includes a BIN,﻿ the dog's microchip details or a rehoming organisation number if the puppy is born on or after December 1, 2025.

A BIN is given free of charge when breeders create a profile on the NSW Pet Registry. (Getty)

Cap on breeding﻿

One of the biggest changes﻿ will be a newly-introduced cap on how many litters a female dog can birth over its lifetime.

There will be a cap of five litters per dog – or three by caesarean.

New breeders will also be required to keep 20 or less non-desexed female dogs over the age of six months on the premises. This law comes into effect a little earlier on November 21.

Finally, there will also be a breeder-to-puppy ratio rule.

The law required breeders to have one staff member to every 20 dogs at a licensed premise.

READ MORE: Huge vote on Epstein files after Trump backflip

Breeders advertising the sale or transfer of dogs will also be required to include key information. (Nine)

Tougher penalties for illegal breeding

The stricter laws come with tougher fines for breeders who don't ﻿comply.

The NSW government can impose a maximum $110,00﻿0 penalty for individuals who keep more than 20 female dogs on the premises without an exemption and $550,000 for corporations.

The same fine applies to exceeding the lifetime breeding limit for a female dog.﻿

Not having a BIN could result in a $11,000 fine, while advertising a pet for sale without the necessary information can incur a $16,500 fine.﻿

Meanwhile, not complying with the staff-to-dog ratio can result in a $44,000 fine for individuals or $220,000 for corporations.﻿

Individuals could also face prison time if the laws are broken.

﻿Minister for Agriculture, Regional and Western NSW Tara Moriarty said the laws will "weed out" the bad actors in the breeding industry.

"These law changes will ensure breeders are held accountable and those in animal welfare law enforcement are given the support they need," Moriarty said.

"We've already banned puppy farms and prevented people convicted of animal cruelty offences from keeping and breeding animals.

"We will continue to take a strong stance on animal welfare."

title: By not checking the time, Aussie workers are losing thousands
text:
Part-time and casual workers are doing more and more unpaid overtime as full-time employees make use of the right-to-disconnect workplace laws.

New research by the Centre for Future Work at The Australia Institute found the average worker was doing 3.5 hours of unpaid overtime each week, or equivalent to more than four and a half full-time weeks per year.

That averages out to about $8000 lost by each worker, or a collective $95.8 billion loss to the entire workforce.﻿

READ MORE: Trump hurls outrageous slur at female reporter

Part-time and casual workers are doing more overtime since the right to disconnect laws came into force. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

The Centre found ﻿that full-time employees averaged 3.8 hours of unpaid overtime a week, compared to 3.7 hours for part-timers.

"The situation for full time workers has stabilised. It's a good first step. I would say, for them, the right to disconnect is working," Centre for Future Work director Fiona Macdonald said.

"But this is the first time we have seen rates of unpaid overtime for part time workers almost as high as full time workers."

READ MORE: Huge vote on Epstein files after Trump backflip

She acknowledged that Australians were too accustomed to offering free overtime to expect rates to plummet instantly.

"The right to disconnect is less effective for part time workers and casuals because they are simply not given enough paid hours to do their jobs," Macdonald said.

"Young people who are already on the lowest incomes are bearing the brunt of this trend towards squeezing part timers."

Highest-paying jobs in Australia that don't need a degree View Gallery

Workers aged 18 to 24 average 4.7 hours a week of unpaid overtime.﻿

"However you look at it, Australian workers are being ripped off," Macdonald said.

"The cost of living crisis isn't over. Now, more than ever, workers should be paid for every single hour they work."

title: More than 70 jobs lost in sudden closure of town's sawmill
text:
T﻿he shock closure of a sawmill in south-east Victoria has put 73 workers out of a job and left the local community devastated.

Staff at the Associated Kiln Driers (AKD) sawmill at Yarram, in Gippsland, yesterday learnt the site was closing just weeks before Christmas.

AKD is the country's biggest softwood producer and has a total Australian workforce of 1000 people.

READ MORE: Aussies sit on 209 million days used leave as jobs market shifts ﻿

A community in Gippsland, eastern Victoria, has been left devastated at news 73 jobs will go with the closure of a local timber mill. (Photo by Angela Wylie). (The Age)

But the Gippsland sawmill has been hit hard by a slowdown in the construction sector and increased operating costs, the company's chief executive Shane Vicary said.

"To remain a sustainable and competitive Australian business, we are adapting to market conditions, simplifying our operations and strengthening the core business at our four major sawmilling sites, which continue to produce the full suite of structural softwood products," he said.

"Having operated in regional communities for 70 years, the significance of our departure from Yarram is not lost on us.

"We understand how important our operations have been to the fabric of this region and we are committed to working with local stakeholders in Gippsland to reduce the impact of the closure where reasonably possible."

Local MP Danny O'Brien said the sudden news of the closure was a devastating blow for the community, which had a jobless rate above the state average.

Timber products have been made at the Yarram sawmill for 70 years, but the site will now close. (The Age)

"Seventy-three jobs lost in a town the size of Yarram is enormous," he told radio station TRFM.

"These are local families, local businesses and a whole community that will feel the impact of this closure immediately.

In a social media post, the Timber, Furnishing and Textiles Union said it was lobbying other timber mills to take some of the impacted workers who lost their jobs at Yarram.

title: Social media use soars as kids drop sports, reading, music
text:
Kids are dropping sport, reading, music,﻿ and the arts as social media use soars, prompting concerns about their development.

New research from the University of South Austral﻿ia found that social media use among children and teens had risen by more than 200 per cent since before the COVID-19 pandemic.

The researchers tracked more than 14,000 South Australian students aged 11 to 14 from 2019 to 2022.

READ MORE: Optus hit with maximum fine over phone scam ﻿

Social media use has soared among adolescents. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Over the four-year period, the number of young people who used social media daily jumped from 26 per cent to 85 per cent.

This correlated with an increase of the proportion of children who never read for fun from 11 per cent to 53 per cent.

The amount of young people who never took part in arts activities rose from 26 per cent to 70 per cent.

READ MORE: Aussies sit on 209 million days of unused leave as job market shifts ﻿

Far fewer young people are reading for fun. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

The proportion of students who never did extra-curricular music activities rose from 70 per cent to 85 per cent.

And non-users of social media went from 31 per cent of the cohort to just 3 per cent.

Boys experienced a steeper drop in reading, while girls consistently used social media more often.

READ MORE: Tropical Cyclone Fina forms off Australian coast ﻿

Music participation has also dropped. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

The researchers said these figures had not reversed in the years since the pandemic restrictions were lifted.

Conversely, time spent watching TV, doing chores, and playing electronic games increased during the pandemic but returned to pre-pandemic levels by 2022.

"There's no doubt that social media has become deeply embedded in children's daily lives. But now it's at the point where it's replacing many of the activities that support healthy development – like sport, reading, and creative play," UniSA researcher and PhD candidate Mason Zhou said.

"Because these changes happened during a critical stage of adolescence, and because they've persisted three years after COVID restrictions ended, they may have lasting impacts on young people's health and wellbeing – and that's a real cause for concern."

With the looming implementation of Australia's social media ban for children under 16, the researchers said this study could show where extra support would be needed for younger teens and children.

Co-researcher Professor Dot Dumuid said more programs and policies that encouraged young people to re-engage in enriching activities such as sport, music, arts, and reading were needed.

Sport helps boost healthy social development. (Getty)

Australia is bringing in a social media ban for under-16s. (Getty)

"If we want to support young people's wellbeing, we need to help them rebalance their time – encouraging them to reconnect with real-world activities that build skills, confidence and social connection," Dumuid said.

"Children who participate in sports, arts and other extra-curricular activities generally have better academic outcomes, stronger self-identity, improved social skills and better mental health."

Dumuid said the dominance of social media posed developmental risks to adolescents.

"The pending social media bans are certainly an intervention aimed at protecting children," she said.

"When access is restricted, children may shift to alternative platforms like gaming, messaging apps or TV. Tracking these behavioural shifts and examining their short- and long-term impacts on young people's health and wellbeing will be important as we move beyond the ban."

The full paper can be found here .

title: Dodgy deals abound in the Black Friday sales - here's how to spot them
text:
Australians are being warned to watch out for dodgy sales tactics and false advertising as the Black Friday sales continue.

The ACCC has already put retailers on notice for misleading or deceptive sales advertising urged consumers to watch out for shopping scams.

Here a consumer law expert breaks down how to spot misleading deals and what to do if you think you've been misled by false advertising during the Black Friday sales.

Aussies are being warned to watch out for dodgy deals in the Black Friday sales. (Getty)

Are Black Friday deals really worth it?

They can be if you shop smart, according to University of Melbourne law professor Jeannie Marie Paterson.

That means watching out for ﻿manipulative advertising tactics like countdowns and timers designed to pressure consumers into overspending.

"Retailers and marketers want people to buy more than they need," Paterson told 9news.com.au.

"People who run marketing campaigns have studied psychology [and] we need to realise that they know more about us than we know about ourselves, so just beware."

How do retailers create fake or misleading discounts?

The ACCC has warned retailers it is on high alert for misleading advertising tactics during the Black Friday sales period, including:

advertising a sale as ﻿'up to X per cent off' but the 'up to' text is not prominently displayed, or few products are on sale at the advertised rate

using misleading time representations (e.g. saying sale is for 'X days only', using a countdown timer) that don't reflect the true duration of the sale

claiming a sale is ﻿store-wide or site-wide when some products are excluded

using fine print or disclaimers to limit ﻿headline claims about a sale (e.g. members-only deals)

using misleading pricing representations that inflate the pre-sale price of a product

Paterson said many of these tactics boil down to creating a misleading sense of pressure for consumers to buy and warned Aussie shoppers to avoid such deals.﻿

Companies caught breaking the rules can face investigations and fines.

Michael Hill, My House and Hairhouse online paid penalties earlier this year for allegedly making false and misleading representations about their Black Friday sales in 2024.

Examples of the type of advertising the ACCC's sweep will focus on. (ACCC)

What can I do if I've been misled by false advertising?

Businesses that mislead consumers through false advertising or claims can be subject to fines and other penalties in Australia.

To protect yourself from potentially ﻿false or misleading advertising, Paterson recommends taking screenshots of online advertisements, product listings, and shopping carts.

It takes just a few seconds and can provide crucial evidence if you don't get what was promised.﻿

If you think you've been a victim of false advertising, you can ﻿ report it to the ACCC.

Is it legal for stores to inflate prices before a sale?

No, but that doesn't stop it from happening.

Some retailers ﻿increase the price of a product before discounting it, resulting in a sale price that seems better than it really is.

This is misleading and illegal, but it's hard for consumers to spot unless they were tracking the product's price﻿ before it went on sale.

Some use ﻿online archives like The Wayback Machine to check a product's price history before buying, but it doesn't always work.

It's better to plan ahead if you want to avoid being duped.

"Go and do some research on the products you might be interested in first," Paterson said.

"Then when sales times comes, you can shop from an informed position that you're getting the discount you actually think you are."

Some Aussies use ﻿online archives to check a product's price history before making Black Friday purchases. (Getty)

What are the most common Black Friday scams to look out for?

Aussies have lost millions to shopping scams already this year and they're currently the most reported scam type involving financial loss in 2025, according to the ACCC.

It's warning consumers to watch out for these scams over the Black Friday sales period.﻿

"Scammers love Black Friday sales too because they know shoppers are looking for bargains and they rely on creating urgency and pressure that can come with a busy shopping period," ACCC Deputy Chair Catriona Lowe said.

"We remind consumers to take their time, check the legitimacy of websites and its offers, and be cautious about sharing personal or financial information online."

Shopping scams initiated through fake websites, advertisements, social media, and mobile apps have already resulted in $122 million in losses this year.

Paterson said that if a Black Friday deal sounds "too good to be true", it probably is.

She also issued a specific warning for the ﻿'ghost store' scam, which has tricked plenty of Aussies out of their hard-earned cash in a matter of minutes.

﻿"Ghost stores are stores that often say they're closing down and selling off their stock, but in fact don't really exist," she explained.

"They're just a scam."

READ MORE: Australia Post reveals deadline for mailing Christmas parcels

Are online deals better than in-store deals?

It depends on the retailer.

Some retailers offer online-exclusive deals, including discounts that may be better than what they can afford to offer in bricks and mortar stores.﻿

"The overheads for retailers selling online are much lower than selling in store," Paterson explained.

"We also know that people are less likely to return products they buy online."

But she warned that digital deals may come with hidden catches.

For example, if you order a product from an overseas retailer your consumer protections will be more limited than if you buy from an Australian business.

"If you buy a product and it's faulty or it doesn't fit, you don't have a lot of return rights," Paterson said.

Can I get a refund on a Black Friday sale item?

It depends.﻿

Some retailers say that products bought in Black Friday sales can't be returned, but ﻿that doesn't override your consumer rights.

﻿"In Australia we have consumer guarantees, which means you do have a right to a refund or replacement for goods that are faulty," Paterson said.

"But there is no legal right for change of mind returns."﻿

The rules also apply to overseas retailers that sell here as Australian law applies to goods sold into Australia, but it may be harder to enforce.

If in doubt, check the fine print before making purchases in the Black Friday sales.

Have you got a story? Contact reporter Maddison Leach at mleach@nine.com.au

title: Ronaldo attends White House dinner with Trump and Saudi crown prince
text:
Soccer superstar Cristiano Ronaldo has had dinner with US President Donald Trump and Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman at the White House.

Mr Trump opened his remarks by thanking some of the guests, including Ronaldo.

The president said he introduced his youngest son, Barron, to the soccer player, adding that his son was impressed with the meeting.

It was unclear why the footballer was in attendance, but the Portuguese striker has been the face of the Saudi football league since 2022.

Donald Trump delivered a speech at the dinner alongside Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. (Reuters: Tom Brenner)

At the black-tie dinner in the White House East Room, Mr Trump welcomed Nvidia chief executive Jensen Huang, tech entrepreneur Elon Musk and other high-profile guests.

FIFA President Gianni Infantino was also in attendance. He has been a regular at the White House this year, ahead of next year's FIFA World Cup.

During dinner, Mr Trump announced he was designating Saudi Arabia as a major non-NATO ally as the administration aims to elevate the two nations' military relationship.

The designation, while largely symbolic, provides foreign partners with certain benefits in the areas of defence, trade and security cooperation.

Ronaldo sees Saudi crown prince as 'boss'

Ronaldo joined football club Al-Nassr at the end of 2022 on a reported $US536.3 million ($865 million) contract.

He has since signed a two-year extension over the summer for a reported $US710 million, which will keep him with Al-Nassr until at least the 2026-27 season.

Al Nassr signed Cristiano Ronaldo in 2022. (Reuters: Ahmed Yosri)

Al-Nassr is majority-owned by the Saudi sovereign wealth fund that the crown prince chairs, and Ronaldo has been the figurehead leading Saudi Arabia's recent investment in its soccer league.

Saudi Arabia teams have invested over $US3 billion into signing some of the best players in the world.

In an interview with Piers Morgan, Ronaldo referred to Prince Mohammed as "our boss".

Earlier this month, he appeared at a Ministry of Tourism event in Riyadh where he talked up the kingdom's development projects and his hopes for the 2034 FIFA World Cup being held in Saudi Arabia.

Ronaldo's US troubles

It was a rare US visit for Ronaldo, who has not played in the country since 2014. It is believed he has not visited the country since that time either.

In 2017, German news magazine Der Spiegel reported that Ronaldo had paid $US375,000 in hush money to a woman who accused him of raping her at a Las Vegas hotel in 2009.

He denied the claims made by Kathryn Mayorga, saying in a statement made in 2018: "Rape is an abominable crime that goes against everything that I am and believe in."

In 2019, US prosecutors said Ronaldo would not face charges because the claims could not be proven.

ABC/Wires

title: SA education minister calls for urgent national inquiry as asbestos sand sites climb to more than 450
text:
South Australia's education chief has called for a national inquiry into how coloured play sand contaminated with asbestos was imported into the country.

The number of sites that have reported stocking the product has climbed to more than 450 in South Australia, according to an updated post on the SA Education Department's website.

"I want to know how this stuff got through our borders, how it ended up on the shelves of major retailers like Kmart and Target and then ended up in schools, preschools and thousands of households," Education Minister Blair Boyer said on Wednesday.

South Australian Minister for Education said the inquiry would examine what checks occur with products like coloured play sand. (ABC News: Lincoln Rothall)

Mr Boyer said he had written to the federal government asking for an inquiry and hoped other jurisdictions would join him in the request.

"What are the checks that occur with products like this?" Mr Boyer said.

"Especially now that we know in cases of a product that was made and marketed towards kids, what checks occur with a product like that?"

Mr Boyer said the inquiry could lead to ensuring an incident like this would not happen again.

"Aside from all the concern that it's caused families, there is a real cost here, that we are wearing to do the clean-up," Mr Boyer said.

"That's money that we won't be able to spend on other things in the education system."

Mr Boyer said the department was expanding the number of contractors in the next couple of days who could facilitate deep cleans at education sites.

"It means we can speed through that process," he said.

Last week, the ACCC issued a national recall notice for various coloured sand products after testing detected traces of asbestos.

That list expanded on Sunday, when further products made in China were identified.

According to the department, the sand has either been secured at a majority of the locations or has been confined to isolated areas.

On Monday, Catholic Education in South Australia said it had temporarily closed two schools to allow for deep cleaning.

title: Nothing like Adelaide uni merger 'has been attempted in Australia before'
text:
When a senate inquiry into university governance kicked off in Adelaide in November, the room was so icy cold it forced South Australian Greens Senator Barbara Pocock to ask a question many had been thinking.

"Is there anyone that can warm this room up, I'm freezing" Senator Pocock said.

There were murmurs of agreement among the small gathering.

But when Senator Pocock later began asking pointed questions about the cost of a contract for Deloitte to support the universities merging to become the new Adelaide University, the temperature in the room turned up.

"So that particular contract around Deloitte, what was the value of it?" Senator Pocock asked.

Adelaide University co-vice chancellor Professor David Lloyd questioned in response: "So this is what I have to ask … does the committee want me to release that publicly?"

He had earlier explained to the senators, the contract with Deloitte was commercial in confidence and the clause was the reason the university had not released the original business case for the merger in full.

"That's why I'm asking if I'm being required to release it now and that's why I'll take that on notice," he told the inquiry.

Professor David Lloyd says "complicated would be an understatement" when describing the university merger. (ABC News)

Adelaide University has been given until November 24 to provide a formal response and the co-vice chancellors have indicated they may release the detail.

"We're reflecting on that and we might well do that," Professor Peter Høj has told ABC News.

"We've just got to make sure that we're able to do that responsibly."

Deloitte has been assisting with the task of amalgamating the University of Adelaide and the University of South Australia, with the merged institution aiming to house a 70,000-strong student cohort and 11,000 staff.

Its projected operation turnover is estimated at about $2.2 billion.

"Nothing like this has been attempted in Australia before … to say it's complicated would be an understatement," Professor David Lloyd said.

He explained Deloitte is working on systems integration — including IT development and data transfer — and operates across mergers and acquisitions, project management and staff training.

"When we undertook to create the new university, we were very cognisant to the fact that we had to run two universities while building a new university," Professor Lloyd said.

"And we had to create the capability and resources to create that new institution without necessarily disrupting the activities of the two."

Adelaide University co-vice-chancellor Peter Høj in a sit-down interview with ABC News Stateline. (ABC News)

Professor Høj added "the complexity of taking two large universities with its myriad of systems and records … is not something I think any organisation in Australia would be able to do on their own and on the time frame required".

"We believe it's absolutely appropriate to get considerable help in and spend money when it's needed and not spend money when it's not needed," he said.

Confusion among students

While there is great interest in the money being spent, for many of the 56,000 continuing students, their sights are set elsewhere.

Naomi Wright, who has been studying journalism at UniSA, said she chose the degree due to its quick pathway through a Masters of Communications.

"I've come in specifically because my masters was going to be one year instead of two, but now looking at the new website the course actually just doesn't exist," she said.

"So I don't know if that means I'm the last group doing it or if I genuinely just won't do it anymore."

Naomi Wright says she has yet to receive her course outline for Masters of Communications. (ABC News)

She said she has received some emails and a chance to join an online discussion forum, but she said there has still been confusion.

"When I've been talking to tutors and people at uni asking them if we're going to be at the same campus next year or if we're doing the same subjects, they just don't know and everyone's just not on the same page," she said.

Ms Wright said part of the problem has been not receiving her course outline, which is known as a study plan.

"I'm sure everything will work out, but right now, not only me, but I know a lot of people will just have no idea what's going on and what to expect next year," she said.

The Adelaide University is set to be one of the largest educators of tertiary students in Australia. (ABC News)

Professor Høj said the delay has been due to Adelaide University creating a new curriculum.

"That means that we have to be extra careful to advise the students appropriately," he said.

"So it's really that complication that has meant that we had to pressure test the study plans."

Professor Lloyd added that the university did not want to provide "information that wasn't accurate".

Date Total study plans released to continuing students October 31 23,000 November 7 37,000 November 14 40,000

The co-vice chancellors said all study plans will be released before December 1, when enrolment opens.

But it is delays like this that have some students like Ms Wright wondering if the universities needed more time to come together.

"A lot of people have said it kind of just feels like we've been bombarded," she said.

"You're starting a new degree, but now it's just all going to change rather than maybe doing it over five or even more years and just slowly bringing it each time."

Adelaide University students have been getting new study plans. (ABC News: Marco Catalano)

Despite it being two years since the South Australian parliament passed legislation that green lit the merger, both co-vice chancellors are resolute setting a January 1, 2026, deadline is the best course of action.

"I guess there's a public phase and there's and there's a there's a not so public phase," Professor Lloyd said.

"Peter and I started talking about this in August of 2021.

"So we've been at this now for over four years in terms of trying to give it the right thought, the right direction, the right incubation.

"We probably could have spent the more time, but whether we would have got a return on that time investment, I guess it's questionable."

title: 'The cost of science has gone up': CSIRO chief defends job cuts
text:
The chief executive of the CSIRO has defended the decision to cut hundreds of jobs, arguing the organisation needs to alter its priorities to remain relevant.

Yesterday, Australia's peak science agency said it had reached a "critical inflection point" and would need to cut up to 350 jobs.

Those jobs are in addition to more than 800 positions that have already been slashed from the organisation in the past 18 months.

Federal Science Minister Tim Ayres said the cuts were aimed at refocusing the efforts of the CSIRO towards research priorities, such as critical minerals, iron and steel production in Australia.

Today, the CSIRO's chief executive said the cuts were being influenced by two main factors.

Cost of living pressure extends to science

"The first is we're looking at our science portfolio as we always should and asking how we can focus it in the areas where CSIRO can make the biggest impact for the country," CSIRO CEO Doug Hilton said.

" Then the second thing is we're facing a really profound sustainability challenge that's been accumulating probably over 40 years. "

Dr Hilton also defended the government's funding of the organisation, saying its budget had not been cut, but that the cost of conducting research had increased significantly.

"What's happened over 15 years is the value of the appropriation that we get, the money we get from the government in the budget each year, has gone up by about 1.3 per cent," he said.

"The cost of living has gone up by about 2.7 per cent on average each year. And the cost of science has gone up much, much more than that."

CSIRO chief executive Doug Hilton says the cost of science has risen along with the cost of living. (Supplied: WEHI)

Dr Hilton said the CSIRO had not yet told staff which areas of research would be targeted by the cuts, but they would be informed "over the next three days in a respectful way".

"We take these decisions very seriously and my heart goes out to the staff, not just the ones that are impacted but the broader CSIRO community," he said.

"We work in a lot of different research areas and I think it is appropriate for us every year to look at those areas where we believe we can generate the most impact.

"And the type of science Australia needs has changed over 50 years. If you think about 10 years ago, no one was talking about AI. Now, we use AI in almost every research area.

"So the skills of our staff, the mix of our staff, the diversity of disciplines that we bring to bear on big problems needs to evolve."

The organisation employs more than 5,800 people in sites across the country. (ABC News: Callum Flinn)

He also defended the decision to announce the redundancies in the lead-up to Christmas.

"In order for us to be able to meet our budget in the 2026-27 year we needed to start that process now and I acknowledge that it is a difficult time to start engaging with staff about those things," he said.

"The timing has been driven by a desire to look at our whole research portfolio. We had 300 of our most senior scientists come together in Melbourne in September and we wanted to take the time to consider their input."

'It's terrifying'

Science and Technology Australia chief executive Ryan Winn today attributed the job cuts to inflation, saying the problem was affecting the entire sector.

"I wouldn't put the blame at Doug's feet," he told ABC Radio Canberra.

"This is government not keeping pace with the investment in science as the cost of everything goes up.

"We're talking 350 jobs. It's great ideas, it's innovations, it's our future.

"This is a problem that's been growing for everyone."

Mr Winn said he had been receiving messages from people since yesterday's announcement, anxious about its wider impact.

"I've had messages from science teachers saying 'How do I convince my kids in my classes to do science now when this is the message government and our sector is sending?'" he said.

" It's terrifying. We know that we need more engineers, more scientists, more AI experts ... How do we convince them that there's real jobs here if all they're hearing is about job cuts? "

Mr Winn pointed to research the CSIRO had done that had led the way in science.

"We have ultra-low gluten-free barley that came out of CSIRO," he said.

"These are amazing ideas that no one else has developed and it's CSIRO that has led these things, so yes, we can do a lot to prioritise and look at how CSIRO can partner with other organisations ... but CSIRO can't do it alone and also universities can't do it alone.

"We've got a great research sector, we just need to back them."

title: Live: Socceroos make solid start against world number 13 Colombia
text:
Colombia is yet to find any real rhythm in New York.

The South Americans are keeping possession well around half-way, but are struggling to find a way forward.

James Rodriguez is dropping quite deep to receive the ball, but we haven't seen any magic from him just yet.

I also wonder how bobbly and difficult to navigate this playing surface is.

It looks pretty uneven out there - especially towards Colombia's right corner flag, where we can see the remnants of a baseball diamond.

title: From meltdown to restart, US nuclear power plant gets a second life
text:
Three Mile Island, once the site of America's worst nuclear power accident, is set to start producing electricity again after the US Department of Energy agreed to a $US1 billion ($1.5 billion) loan.

The nuclear power plant, on an island in the Susquehanna River just outside Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, is under contract to supply power to data centres for tech giant Microsoft.

It was the site of the nation's worst commercial nuclear power accident in 1979.

Google, Microsoft to reopen nuclear plants to power AI Google has announced a nuclear facility shuttered in 2020 will return to service in 2029 to help power its "growing cloud and AI infrastructure in Iowa", a year after Microsoft signed on to reopen Three Mile Island.

The loan is in line with the priorities of US President Donald Trump's administration, including bolstering nuclear power and artificial intelligence.

For Constellation Energy, which owns Three Mile Island's lone functioning nuclear power reactor, the federal loan will lower its financing cost to get the mothballed plant up and running again.

The 835-megawatt reactor can power the equivalent of approximately 800,000 homes, the US Department of Energy says.

The reactor had been out of operation for five years when Constellation Energy announced last year that it would spend $US1.6 billion ($2.4bn) to restart it under a 20-year agreement with Microsoft to buy the power for its data centres.

Constellation Energy renamed the functioning unit the Crane Clean Energy Center as it works to restore equipment including the turbine, generator, main power transformer and cooling and control systems.

Japan's nuclear gamble Why a country stricken by one of the worst nuclear disasters of all time is ready for more reactors.

The company hopes to bring the plant back online in 2027.

The loan is being issued under an existing $US250 billion ($383 billion) energy infrastructure program initially authorised by the US Congress in 2022.

Neither the department nor Constellation has released the terms of the loan.

Accident in 1979

The plant was the site of the nation's worst commercial nuclear power accident in 1979.

The accident destroyed one reactor, Unit 2, and left the plant with one functioning reactor, Unit 1.

In 2019, Constellation Energy's then-parent company Exelon shut down the functioning reactor, saying it was losing money and Pennsylvania lawmakers had refused to subsidise it to keep it running.

The plan to restart the reactor comes amid a renaissance for nuclear power, as policymakers are increasingly looking to it to shore up the nation's power supply to meet rising power demand driven by data centres, particularly with the growth of AI.

AP

title: Wage growth remains steady, just ahead of inflation
text:
Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) figures show workers received an average base pay increase of 3.4 per cent over the year to September, in line with the previous quarter and economist forecasts.

That pay rise has again slightly outpaced consumer price inflation, which rose to 3.2 per cent over the same period. It means the average worker saw a small increase in their purchasing power.

Inflation surges to 3.2pc in September quarter Inflation data has came in much hotter than economists were expecting with annual inflation surging to 3.2 per cent in the September quarter, up from 2.1pc in June.

However, the annual pay increase was slightly down on the same period a year earlier, when workers saw their base pay packets rise 3.5 per cent on average.

JP Morgan economist Tom Kennedy said workers could expect to see their real wages — adjusted for inflation — fall again next year.

"The recent upturn in inflation means that real wage growth has also turned lower, running at just +0.2 per cent and likely to turn negative in the coming quarters as headline inflation approaches 3.5 per cent," he said.

Workers in the public sector, especially state government employees, earned more than those in the private sector. (Unsplash: Glenn Carstens-Peters)

This tallies with recent Reserve Bank forecasts in its Statement on Monetary Policy, which also tipped inflation to outpace pay rises for much of 2026.

This year's pay rise was also stronger for workers in the public sector (3.8 per cent) compared to the private sector (3.2 per cent).

The head of prices statistics at the ABS, Michelle Marquardt, said those mostly went to state, not federal or local, government employees.

"State government pay rises contributed 82 per cent of public sector wage growth this quarter," Ms Marquardt said.

Abhijit Surya, from Capital Economics, said the relative weakness of private sector pay rises, which were propped up by an increase in minimum and award wages, should comfort the Reserve Bank that wage rises are not a major contributor to inflation pressures.

"Encouragingly, though, wage growth for workers on individual arrangements, which tends to be more sensitive to cyclical conditions, did ease slightly, from 3.1 per cent to 3 per cent," he noted.

"Looking further ahead, our composite labour market continues to suggest that wage growth will fall to around 3 per cent in the coming quarters, as the [Reserve] Bank is expecting.

"With productivity growth in the midst of a cyclical rebound, unit labour cost growth should ease in tandem, helping to tame services inflation."

Wage growth peaked at 4.2 per cent in the December quarter of 2023, after remaining stuck below 2.5 per cent from the start of 2015 to early 2022.

The Wage Price Index (WPI) measures base pay, and does not include additional payments like overtime and bonuses.

The ABS published a second set of monthly numbers today, estimating the total wages and salaries paid by employers to their staff in September.

Payments totalled $108.8 billion, driven higher by bonuses in the mining, utilities, retail, media and financial services sectors, which are often paid in September, in response to financial year targets.

However, the 5.3 per cent annual growth in total wages and salaries paid to employees was down from the 6.1 per cent rise recorded over the year to September 2024.

title: New crop could be Australia's sustainable aviation fuel sweet spot
text:
It has not been grown here for almost a century, but as the need for sustainable aviation fuels intensifies, sugar beet could be making an Australian comeback.

Biofuel company Sky Renewables has partnered with eight central Queensland farmers to trial growing the crop as a feedstock for renewable energy.

Traditionally grown in Europe, Russia and the United States to produce sugar, beets were first grown in Victoria's Gippsland region in the late 1800s, but the industry collapsed after World War II.

Sugar beet is grown in places like Russia, Europe and the United States. ( Flickr: Sugar Beets/arbyreed/CC BY-NC sa 2.0)

Already working with the industry that came to replace it — sugar cane — the company's chief executive Simon Yim hopes beets will prove superior when it comes to fuel.

As the Queensland government holds its own hearings into sugar's bioenergy opportunity, the industry is hopeful the COP30 climate talks in Brazil will set clear targets to incentivise further investment.

Waste game

In the Burdekin region near Townsville in north Queensland, Mr Yim works with canegrowers to produce biomethane, a renewable natural gas.

"We are trying to persuade the growers to abandon burning the cane field before harvesting so that we can take the tops and trash and use it as a feedstock," he said.

Simon Yim is the founder and CEO of biofuel company Sky Renewables. (ABC Capricornia: Claudia Sullivan)

But 600 kilometres to the south, around Emerald, where cotton and grains are the staple crops, eight growers have signed up to work with the company over the next two years.

Mr Yim said the beets would be trialled as a winter rotational crop, extracting the sugar juice to ethanol, an ingredient in biofuel.

"This is probably the best, simplest and lowest carbon intensity feedstock to make bioethanol," Mr Yim said.

He said the lack of infrastructure made beets unviable as a sugar crop when compared to the established cane industry, but as a water-efficient feedstock for the fledgling biofuel industry, it stacked up.

"Right now, what was considered waste just a few years ago [has] become valuable," he said.

" Using waste to make bioenergy is the name of the game. "

Shahana McKenzie, the chief executive of industry representative body Bioenergy Australia, said there were positive signs that value was being recognised globally.

Shahana McKenzie says regional and rural Australia are in a unique position to capitalise on the interest in biofuels. (Supplied: Bioenergy Australia)

"There has been a very strong focus on decarbonisation of the electricity sector globally," she said.

"It's really good to see that now there is this focus moving towards low-carbon liquid fuels and renewable gases."

Two years ago, global leaders agreed to transition away from oil, gas and coal at the COP28 climate talks in Dubai, but the deal was criticised for failing to set actionable targets.

Qantas has committed to 10 per cent sustainable aviation fuel from 2030. (ABC News: Keana Naughton)

Ms McKenzie said the most recent climate talks in Brazil had the opportunity to drive global market development by addressing the shortage of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF).

"It sets a global ambition," she said.

"It sends a signal out globally across the countries to say this is now an area of focus."

Sustainable momentum

In September, the Australian government announced a $1.1 billion program to promote biofuel manufacturing and development, in a bid to provide decarbonised fuel options to hard-to-abate sectors like aviation.

Mr Yim said international interest in SAF production had accelerated since Europe set a minimum supply mandate, which requires fuel at EU airports to contain a minimum of 2 per cent SAF in 2025, increasing to 70 per cent by 2050.

"SAF is a global need," he said.

"For example, Qantas has committed to 10 per cent SAF in their tanks starting in 2030."

Ms McKenzie said regional and rural Australia was in a unique position to capitalise on the interest.

"What we have seen over the past 12 months is absolutely a strong focus from businesses out of the US as well as Europe looking at Australia and saying, hang on, there's a lot of feedstock there," she said.

"With that feedstock in the regions, we can be providing economic returns into regional Australia.

"If we're talking about the low-carbon fuels and renewable gas projects, we're talking about thousands of jobs, we're talking an additional 10 billion GDP."

Australia's sugar industry has been pushing to expand into biofuel for years. (ABC News: Brad Marsellos)

In Queensland, that opportunity is being explored through an inquiry into sugarcane bioenergy opportunities.

Hearings resume in Brisbane on November 19. Among those providing submissions is the peak industry body for the sugarcane milling sector, Australian Sugar Manufacturers.

"The sugar industry can supply over 30 per cent of Australia's domestic aviation fuel needs," chief executive Ash Salardini said.

"Sugar-derived biofuels [can] provide affordable biogas to regional manufacturers and replace coal to make steel production green with renewable pellets made from sugar by-products.

"This agenda will create thousands of new jobs in places like Bundaberg, Mackay, Townsville and Cairns, and will attract more manufacturing businesses to regional Queensland through access to affordable energy and secure the long-term viability of the sugar industry that already supports 20,000 jobs."

The committee intends to table an interim report on December 15, 2025, with a final report due on June 12, 2026.

title: Queensland men's shed still without a home after being evicted
text:
It might be a little rough on the outside, but this rundown tin shed has been a home for the silver-haired blokes of Gympie for more than a decade.

After 12 years in the heart of town, the Gympie Men's Shed needs to find new premises, and it is proving a difficult task.

The members were notified in June that their tenancy at the Old Gympie Railway Station would not be renewed, but, after months of searching, they are about to be "men without a shed".

The group says it has struggled to find a suitable industrial site with property scarce in the region. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jake Kearnan)

Shed secretary Jack Menhenik said safety concerns were cited in the eviction notice.

"Queensland Rail has been really good to us over the last 12 years in this vicinity, which has got three sheds, a communal block, a toilet and kitchen facilities," Mr Menhenik said.

" They're a bit concerned about the safety of the building. There's asbestos … I'm sure there is asbestos in every government building, the roof is leaking, and [there are] a few other things. "

The shed is downsizing its operation into storage as the search for another space continues.

"We're doing a lot of dump runs, we've had this garage sale going on for four weeks, and we've been trying for months to find a new space," Mr Menhenik said.

"Real estate in the area is scarce."

The men's shed will meet once a month after its members vacate the premises as they search for a new site. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jake Kearnan)

According to the Real Estate Institute of Queensland (REIQ), Gympie's rental vacancy rate currently sits at 1.2 per cent, 0.2 per cent higher than the state average but in line with the national rate of 1.2 per cent.

Meanwhile, the median house price has more than doubled from $322,000 to $750,000 in the past five years.

It has made finding a new home difficult.

President of the Gympie Men's Shed Markcus Jaques said the members had been working tirelessly to clear out the site.

"A lot of us have been going home, getting in our lounge chairs, falling asleep and not waking up until the next morning," Mr Jaques said.

"Most of us are over 65, and it's a lot to ask.

"Some of the blokes reckon I've been getting the whip out.

"Since we've closed, my phone hasn't stopped ringing from partners and wives saying, 'What am I going to do with my husband now?'

A closing down sale is being held at the old site on Tozer Street. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jake Kearnan)

Uncertain future

Men's sheds across the country have long played an important role in creating a community environment and a sense of belonging for men of all ages.

Mr Menhenik said membership numbers had dwindled since the news.

"We had 70 members; at the moment we've only got about 35 on the books," he said.

"A few of the guys haven't renewed, citing that we don't have a home.

"We meet three times a week from around 8am to midday, and there's three or four members that only turn up for the coffee break — it gets them out of the house."

Jack Menhenik said the group had concerns about the welfare of its members if they are unable to meet regularly. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jake Kearnan)

There were fears the group would lose the money it had raised over the years.

"We're a not-for-profit organisation … if we did fold, we would lose that money," Mr Menhenik said.

"That would go to the Australian Men's Shed Association, which is what the constitution says, and there is nothing wrong with that, but … these guys have done sausage sizzles and sold a heap of equipment to make money for the Gympie Men's Shed."

While the search for a new home has been unfruitful thus far, the club is hopeful someone will come to the table with a suitable site.

The group has been working tirelessly to move all its equipment into storage. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jake Kearnan)

End of an era

The club was given a three-month grace period to vacate the premises following the expiry of its lease in June.

Queensland Rail's head of SEQ, Neil Backer, said it was unable to continue the token lease due to site defects.

"Queensland Rail has been working with the Gympie Men's Shed for several months, and all attempts have been made to find them a new location," Mr Backer said.

"Unfortunately, this has not been possible."

Queensland Rail will continue to provide the men's group with a shed for storage on site for up to two years while they source a new home.

title: Scotland ends 28-year World Cup absence after breathtaking bicycle kick goal
text:
A superb bicycle kick goal from Scott McTominay has helped Scotland reach the World Cup finals for the first time since 1998.

The Scots qualified for next year's finals in North America and Mexico with a 4-2 victory over Denmark in front of a boisterous home crowd at Glasgow's Hampden Park.

Denmark, who only needed to avoid defeat to secure its third successive World Cup finals appearance, was stunned in the third minute when McTominay scored a magical goal for the ages.

Appearing to defy gravity, McTominay soared high into the air to meet a Ben Gannon-Doak cross with an overhead kick that gave Denmark goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel no chance.

McTominay's goal lit up social media, with Scottish sporting great Andy Murray among those astonished by his effort.

"What on earth was that," Murray wrote on X.

"McTominay you wee dancer!"

Scotland went on to clinch its World Cup finals berth after stoppage-time goals from Kieran Tierney and Kenny McLean.

When Patrick Dorgu equalised at 2-2 in the 81st minute, it seemed 10-man Denmark would secure the point it needed to top Group C and book its place in next year's finals.

But after a rollercoaster qualifying campaign for the Scots, the biggest twist of the evening was saved for the end.

The ball came out to Tierney in the third minute of stoppage time, before he looked up and curled a superb left-footed shot past a diving Schmeichel.

The drama was not over, though.

Schmeichel was found way out of his goal when McLean launched a shot from the halfway line into the empty net.

Lyndon Dykes celebrates Scotland's triumph at Hampden Park. (Getty Images/UEFA: Alex Livesey)

"That just sums up this squad. Never say die," Scotland captain Andy Robertson said.

"We just keep going right to the end and one of the craziest games.

"We put the country through it, but I'm sure it's worth it. We're going to the World Cup."

Earlier, Denmark levelled in the 57th minute after McTominay's stunning goal.

A Robertson foul on Gustav Isaksen was adjudged to have been just inside the penalty area and Rasmus Højlund made no mistake from the spot.

Minutes later, Rasmus Kristensen was shown a second yellow card and when Lawrence Shankland touched in a corner to put Scotland ahead, it looked like that would be enough.

Spain through to World Cup finals

Spain booked its spot at the World Cup finals after a nervy 2-2 draw with Turkey in Seville, finishing unbeaten at the top of Group E.

Switzerland also qualified, despite being held 1-1 by Kosovo, while Belgium hammered Liechtenstein 7-0 to confirm its finals berth.

Austria's Marcel Sabitzer celebrates qualifying for the World Cup finals. (Reuters: Lisa Leutner)

Austria advanced to its first World Cup finals appearance since 1998.

The Austrians snatched a 77th-minute equaliser against Bosnia and Herzegovina to earn a 1-1 draw.

Reuters/AP

title: After 15 years of democracy, is Tonga turning back to its king?
text:
On Thursday, the people of the Kingdom of Tonga will head to the ballot box for only the fifth general election in its history.

As the only remaining sovereign monarchy in the Pacific, the Kingdom, as it is known colloquially, is still young democratically, with most of the country's parliament being elected by the people for the first time in 2010.

Yet, in spite of the recent — and long heralded — milestones of political evolution, there is concern among some that Tonga is, already, slipping back into an autocracy.

"What we are witnessing is a reversal of democratic changes that happened in 2010," said Lopeti Senituli, a political commentator and former advisor to two prime ministers.

"What we agreed to in 2010 was a power-sharing arrangement between the king and a democratically elected prime minister and cabinet … that was what we agreed to."

Lopeti Senituli is concerned by some of the political manouvres being made in Tonga. (ABC News)

Thursday's general election occurs less than a year after the former prime minister Siaosi Sovaleni resigned in parliament, just minutes after a motion for a vote of no-confidence was passed against him.

The public reasons given for the motion were alleged corruption and mismanagement, but there was widespread speculation the motion was the result of a power struggle between the prime minister and King Tupou VI.

Just weeks prior to Sovaleni's resignation, a dispute between the PM and king became public when a letter from Tonga's Royal Palace was leaked, revealing the king's disapproval of Sovaleni's foreign minister at the time, Fekita 'Utoikamanu.

The letter was later publicly rebuked by Sovaleni. Soon after, Sovaleni was replaced by the now Prime Minister 'Aisake Eke, and parliament passed legislation handing full control of Tonga's foreign affairs to the monarchy, renaming it "His Majesty's Diplomatic Service".

Mr Senituli said the move was an example of changes being made "without consulting the public".

Mr Sovaleni himself is on the ballot paper and widely predicted to win his constituency, with the prospect of being re-elected as prime minister a possibility.

Mr Senituli believes Mr Sovaleni has a good chance of returning to the top job, while others say the breakdown in relationship with the king leaves him with no chance.

Some, such as Tongan noble representative Lord Tu'ilakepa, go further.

He believes the prime minister position should be decided by the king, effectively reversing the democratic reforms of 2010.

Lord Tu'ilakepa has advocated for more radical changes to Tonga's politics. (ABC News)

"Let the king choose the prime minister from the 26 MPs," he told the ABC.

"If that happens, all these quarrels will stop.

"Right now, you have individuals lobbying and calling around trying to secure the PM position.

"What's crucial is for the people's representatives to stand united — but realistically, they never will. They have different political ideologies."

Tonga's tough democratic experience

Tonga's 15 years as a democracy has been arduous.

In that short period, four out of five prime ministers have faced a vote of no confidence, 10 MPs have been convicted for corruption and bribery, and at one point, the country's parliament was dissolved for nearly four months.

Despite being recognised as a democracy, Tonga's political system still faces international and domestic criticism for allocating more than a third of parliament seats to "noble representatives" — MPs elected by a pool of just 33 hereditary chiefs and a handful of life peers.

Elections in the country have been peaceful and results have been undisputed, but frictions between cabinet and the monarchy and nobles have been ongoing.

There's a mixed reaction about the balance of powers within Tonga's political system, a system largely based on the United Kingdom's Westminster system — one which recognises the monarch as the head of state but a government directed by a democratically elected parliament.

"At the moment the parliament is unable to check itself, so the king has to get involved in the political process," said Tevita Motulalo, a long-time journalist and political commentator.

"I would prefer to have two chamber system with lower and upper house, because there are greater checks in place.

"The nobles are representatives of their territories and ha'a [tribe] … it's similar to that of a senator who comes in as representative of a state/province."

Tongans want better infrastructure and social support

On the streets of the capital Nuku'alofa, the tension between the palace and the politicians is not front of mind.

As they head to the ballot box, it's the economy, basic infrastructure, healthcare and crime.

"The biggest challenge that I'm seeing in my neighbourhood are the poor state of the roads … they're damaged and full of potholes," said one woman in Nuku'alofa.

"I'm looking to a government that prioritises education, health and security," said another.

"A lot of youth are using drugs … I feel like the government hasn't done enough for youth," said a man in the Tongatapu village of Vaotu'u.

The ABC spoke to Tongan voters ahead of the 2025 poll to get their views on what would shape their decisions at the ballot box. (ABC News)

"I will vote for the person who has love for the poor. Like myself, I'm not well off and I'd like someone who helps the poor. One thing I think could be improved is the pension for elderly people, these are the people who worked to build this country."

Tonga has endured persistent fuel shortages, with hours-long queues being a common sight at petrol stations.

Potholes dot almost every road and a number of resorts have closed down as a result of natural disasters.

The public sector is suffering from a severe labour shortage due to mass emigration and overseas labour mobility which has seen thousands of Tongans regularly travel to Australia and New Zealand to pick fruit and pack meat.

"As a single voter issue, democratic reform is no longer centre stage," said Mr Motulalo.

"The majority of the discussions in the election campaigns is about livelihoods, education, health and so forth."

The King 'flexes his muscles' in Tonga Tonga's king has taken control of a government department in what critics say is a 'slap' to democracy in the Pacific nation.

For long time pro-democracy advocates like Mr Senituli, however, the monarch's increasing influence in the running of the country is worrying.

He says it could be just one step in the erosion of Tonga's democratic reforms.

"Now we are slowly witnessing the king re-inserting his executive authority and this is a step backwards," he said.

"This is what I'm worried about, that the democratic changes that we have made are going to be lost."

title: Jess Wilson faces climate change grilling on first day as Victorian Liberal leader
text:
Jess Wilson has started her first full day as Victorian Liberal leader by refusing to distance her party's climate change policies from its federal counterpart, which was criticised last week for dumping the commitment to net zero emissions.

She also reaffirmed the party's commitment to repeal the state's first treaty with Aboriginal people, which was signed earlier this month.

The federal Liberal Party last week dumped its commitment to achieving net zero emissions by 2050, despite action on climate change being seen as a key issue for younger voters.

Ms Wilson declined to commit to a net zero policy in Victoria but said her party had supported emissions reduction legislation in the parliament.

"There's no plans to change what legislation has gone through the parliament but what we are doing is we are saying we have to focus on the fact that power bills keep increasing and that we have a gas shortfall in future years and that's why we have been very clear that we want gas to be part of that transition," she told ABC Radio Melbourne.

After the federal Liberal Party ditched its net zero commitment, then-Victorian Liberal leader Brad Battin said he was "comfortable" retaining Victoria's goal of net zero emissions by 2045.

But on Wednesday Ms Wilson would not repeat that commitment.

"We have been clear in our position in the parliament in supporting emissions reduction targets here in Victoria, but what I'm saying is it can't be by itself," she said.

" We have to make sure people are actually able to pay their power bills. "

She also indicated she did not differ from her predecessor, Brad Battin, in her plans for the state's treaty with Aboriginal people, which the government signed into law with much fanfare.

"We've been very clear that we oppose the treaty and will repeal it when we come into government," she said.

Jess Wilson has become the third Liberal party leader in less than three months following a leadership spill. (AAP Image: Joel Carrett)

Ms Wilson was keen to market her arrival as leader as a fresh start for the party, just a year out from the next state election.

"Yesterday was a line in the sand moment. We have elected a new generational team and a team that represents all walks of life from all across Victoria," she said.

"As a millennial, I'm 35, I understand the pressures of that generation and below, and a lot of it comes back to home ownership.

"So many young people in Victoria have simply lost hope that they will ever be able to afford their own home, and I want to put forward the policies that restore that hope."

Signs the party is still divided on leadership

Ms Wilson ousted Mr Battin yesterday after a motion to spill the leadership divided the Liberal Party, 19 votes to 13.

After the party voted for the spill, Ms Wilson was elected unopposed.

On Wednesday morning, Mr Battin offered his full support to the new party leader who would take them to the polls in 2026.

"Look, I think we've got a really good chance," he said.

"Jess is going to be in a great position to win. We've seen that Victorians really want change, and Jess is the right person now to take us to the next election.

"Victorians just want to see that the Victorian Liberal Party can deliver. We've already come out with some good policies we'll continue."

Brad Battin was dumped after less than a year as Victorian Liberal leader. (ABC News: ABC News)

Senior Lecturer in Politics and International Relations at Monash University Zareh Ghazarian said the 19-13 split in the spill vote showed there was still disagreement in the party.

"This shift to a new leader wasn't unanimous, Brad Battin still did have supporters and there are still going to be divisions within the Liberal party," Dr Ghazarian said.

" It's this weird conundrum where it doesn't necessarily mean that if a leader is popular, they're going to keep their job. "

Dr Ghazarian said the divisions within the party would need to be fixed quickly to avoid the situation repeating.

"There are 12 months until the next election, which is due this time next year," he said.

"If they are still unable to reconcile their differences, especially between those with more socially conservative views and those with slightly more progressive views, then the party is probably going to be going through this loop regularly."

Former Liberal premier Jeff Kennett called it an "exciting" development for the party.

"This is a generational change, it's a generational change for the Liberal party," he said.

" I think you will find that she'll not only attract young people to her style, but I think she'll also attract a lot of those senior women who have been attracted to the Teals in recent years but who are fundamentally Liberal supporters. "

Former premier Jeff Kennett says Ms Wilson represents generational change in the party. (ABC News)

Mr Kennett said the party had been bogged down in factional warfare for years, and would benefit from the leadership of a relative "cleanskin" to politics.

"There have been people who have been working to undermine successive leaders," he said.

"The very fact they have, as factions, come together and said we need change … gives me great hope."

title: Alcaraz 'heartbroken' after withdrawing from Davis Cup Finals
text:
World number one Carlos Alcaraz says he is "heartbroken" after pulling out of Spain's squad for the Davis Cup Finals in Bologna because of a swollen hamstring.

Alcaraz aggravated the injury during the ATP Finals in Turin, where he lost to Jannik Sinner in the tournament decider on Monday AEDT.

"I'm so sorry to announce that I won't be able to play for Spain in the Davis Cup in Bologna," Alcaraz wrote on Instagram.

Sinner claims ATP Finals victory over Alcaraz Jannik Sinner has defeated world number one Carlos Alcaraz 7-6 (4), 7-5 in the ATP Finals title decider.

"I have edema [swelling] in my right hamstring, and the medical recommendation is not to compete.

"I've always said that playing for Spain is the greatest thing there is, and I was really looking forward to helping us fight for the Davis Cup.

"I'm going home heartbroken."

Alcaraz's withdrawal dealt another blow to Davis Cup organisers, the International Tennis Federation.

Sinner, ranked number two in the world, pulled out of the Davis Cup Finals last month before defending champions Italy confirmed his absence.

Italy, which has won the past two Davis Cups, will also be without world number eight Lorenzo Musetti, who withdrew citing physical and family reasons.

Musetti's place is expected to be taken by Lorenzo Sonego, who has been in Turin practising in recent days.

Italy faces Austria in the quarterfinals on Thursday morning AEDT, while Spain plays Czechia on Friday AEDT.

Reuters

title: How to watch the AFL draft and everything else you need to know
text:
Another AFL draft has arrived, offering dozens of teenage footballers the chance to realise their dreams and clubs the opportunity to prepare for a brighter future.

The draft can be a complicated beast these days, with academies and father-son selections muddying the waters for clubs looking to secure the best talent.

Here is everything you need to know about the 2025 AFL draft and tap here for a rundown of every pick for each team.

When is the AFL draft?

The 2025 AFL draft will be held over two nights on Wednesday, November 19 and Thursday, November 20.

The first round will be completed tonight, when a selection of players will be present at Docklands Stadium for the event.

The rest of the draft will be held on the second night. In total, 50 to 60 players are expected to be drafted this year.

How can I follow the AFL draft?

ABC Sport will have live blogs running on both nights of the draft, bringing you news and analysis of every pick.

The draft will also be broadcast live on Fox Footy and Kayo Sports.

What time is the AFL draft?

Both nights of the draft will start at 7pm AEDT.

Here are the corresponding times for other regions of Australia.

6:30pm ACDT: South Australia

South Australia 6pm AEST: Queensland

Queensland 5:30pm ACST : Northern Territory

: Northern Territory 4pm AWST: Western Australia

Who are the players I should know before the draft?

It is widely expected that Willem Duursma — the fourth Duursma sibling to join the AFL/AFLW system — will be taken by West Coast with the first selection on Wednesday night.

Willem Duursma is set to be the number one pick at this year's draft. (Getty Images: Paul Kane)

Others in the top-five mix are Zeke Uwland and Dylan Patterson (both members of Gold Coast's academy), Daniel Annable (a member of Brisbane's academy) and Harry Dean (a Carlton father-son).

From the open pool of players available to all, Cooper Duff-Tytler, Sullivan Robey, Xavier Taylor, Sam Cumming and Dyson Sharp are the strongest top-10 candidates.

What is the current order of picks in the first round?

West Coast West Coast Richmond Richmond Essendon Essendon Melbourne Melbourne Carlton Hawthorn Carlton GWS West Coast Western Bulldogs Gold Coast Adelaide Brisbane Gold Coast Geelong Fremantle Essendon Hawthorn Brisbane

How does the bidding system work in the AFL draft?

The AFL assigns each draft pick with a points value. The first pick in the draft has the most value, with 3,000 points, and the points value of each pick decreases all the way down until pick 54, the final pick of the third round, which is worth 14 points. Any picks from then onwards have no points value.

Brisbane will swiftly match a bid for academy prospect Daniel Annable. (Getty Images: Josh Chadwick)

The points system is in place for two reasons: to require clubs to pay for matching bids on father-son prospects or academy prospects that are tipped to go high up in any given draft year.

Teams who match bids for either a father-son or academy prospect get a 20 per cent discount. Teams are not obligated to match bids from other clubs, therefore allowing the player to be drafted by a different club.

Can teams do trades during the draft?

They sure can!

Since being introduced in 2018, the ability for teams to trade during the draft has added an extra wrinkle to the whole process.

Teams can trade with each other using their own picks in the current draft as well as using picks in the 2026 or 2027 drafts.

What is the father-son rule?

The father-son rule is one that is unique to the AFL and allows family traditions to be carried through generations.

Simply put, if a player makes 100 or more appearances for a single club, then that same club has the right to draft the player's son.

There have been some famous father-son combinations to have played in VFL/AFL history, perhaps none more famous than Gary Ablett and Gary Ablett Jr, who both played for Geelong.

Teams are not obligated to select a player under the father-son rule either. A famous example of this occurred in the 2015 draft when the Sydney Swans opted against drafting Josh Dunkley — now a three-time premiership player — whose father, Andrew, played 217 games for the club.

title: Regional shire warns state rate reforms would bankrupt council
text:
An outback local government says it could be bankrupted, as a "David and Goliath" battle moves through the West Australian parliament's upper house.

Last week, the lower house passed an amendment to the Local Government Act which would block shires from rating certain mining land.
